summary: The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia today entered a final judgment against Dese Terrell Johnson, Jr., a convicted felon who was sentenced to 30 years of probation for a previous felony conviction.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Alexandria, Virginia on August 23, 2016, Johnson, then a resident of Port Royal, Virginia, was arrested on May 30, 2016. The complaint alleges that the two females, ages 16 and 17, were approached by Johnson while at the Dollar Tree or Dollar General, and that Johnson told the girls his name was Justice and he goes by “J.” The complaint further alleges that one of the females told the other party that he "was a convicted sex offender.  He had just been released from eight years' imprisonment for [robbery,] a crime of violence.  The complaint charges Johnson with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, Johnson consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the federal securities laws, and orders him to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and an officer-and-director bar.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Johnson. The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by John Rymas of the SEC Enforcement Division's Cyber Unit. The case is being supervised by Kelly L. Gibson. The litigation will be led by Mr. Gibson and Ms. Gagnon and supervised by C.J. Kerstetter.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Virginia State Police, and the Virginia Attorney General's Office in this matter.
